I am unable to reproduce the timeout issue, but according to the exception raised, pytest terminated the test after 3600 while it was stuck at:
  File "/home/stack/src/x/tobiko/tobiko/shell/sh/_ssh.py", line 110, in create_process
    process = client.get_transport().open_session()

It seems paramiko timeout for opening a session/channel is 3600 seconds.
So, it looks reasonable to me that adding a lower timeout (I think 20 seconds to open an ssh channel should be enough) helps with this (remember tobiko is going to retry if this timer expires)

So in case that there is a machine that has just been rebooted, wouldn't we like to wait a little more than 20 seconds until it is active again?
Or do we prefer to assign that responsibility (the "correct" timeout value) to the test runner (user)?

Some ubuntu tests failing due to this patch: https://b11d2f0d913d6e1bddf3-ae8883cb3588e5f69259a18f0382f4bd.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/858015/2/check/devstack-tobiko-functional/0efdb76/tobiko_results_functional.html

The 20 seconds value from this patch only applies to the paramiko open_session operation.
I (wrongly?) thought it was a value that made sense:
- the ssh connection is already established (see line #110 at _ssh.py)
- if the open_session operation (line #111) fails after 15 seconds, most probably it will never recover (and better not to wait for one hour, its default value)
- important: I verified a command that takes more than 20 seconds doesn't fail due to this 20 seconds timer; I insist this timer only applies to the open_session operation

Maybe my second assumption is wrong and I should use a greater value.



On the other hand, I believe there is something wrong with the tobiko retries mechanism here:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/bF6cBSP3z8k5pFvaetlm/

More specifically, between these two lines, only 46 seconds pass, but the elapsed_time changes from 0.0 to 291.3:
2022-09-16 10:43:03.430 118565 DEBUG tobiko.shell.sh._ssh - Error creating remote process. (command='mktemp -d', current_dir='None', login=ubuntu@172.24.5.29:22, timeout=120.0, attempt=retry_attempt(number=1, count=3, elapsed_time=0.0, timeout=120.0, interval=5.0), environment=None)
2022-09-16 10:43:49.753 118565 DEBUG tobiko.shell.sh._ssh - Error creating remote process. (command='mktemp -d', current_dir='None', login=ubuntu@172.24.5.29:22, timeout=0.0, attempt=retry_attempt(number=2, count=3, elapsed_time=291.3230137825012, timeout=120.0, interval=5.0), environment=None)

I'll continue investigating...

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: IMO, it makes sense to stop after first fail in disruptive workflow. In case environment is broken after a disruptive test I would expect multiple test failures due to the same reason. Also full test execution can be too long in this case due to long timeouts, i.e. in case some vm is unresponsive test will try till timeout (e.g. test can take 15-30 minutes  instead of 1-2). And if there will be many such test the job will probably timeout as well.

Thanks for the comment, Roman. I think you are right. I changed my vote.

I have been taking a look at the downstream job and have some new comments:
- the neutron_faults tests execute all the faults tests (it should only run tests under faults/neutron directory) because of an issue with tox 4 that we recently fixed (by using tox 3): https://review.opendev.org/c/x/tobiko/+/867985
- it seems to me that the tests under faults/containers/ are not testing any disruption - they just test neutron configuration and neutron log files - in my opinion, they are sanity tests and should be moved to the proper path
- if those tests are moved under the sanity directory, in case they fail, they will not affect the rest of the sanity tests, which will be executed regardless other failures

specs/pike/backup_share.rst.message: Maybe it's just me, but I'm not getting the point here about the need for a "backup copy" in addition to the backups themselves.

When we createing a backup with a policy, the policy could be set to "max_copy_num=10, interval=1h", it means we create a share backup task, the task will automatic create 10 share backup copies and every copies interval time is 1 hours in this share backup. We could easily change our policy, maybe we could extend the max copy number or anything else. It will easy control by policy.

Can you explain the copy operation here?

In the case of cinder NFS backup (and any "chunked" backup) the source is a block device so the copy operation for a full backup is a literal copy of the "chunks" (fixed sequences of blocks of data) for the whole device.  It is basically the equivalent of a 'dd' command.  And incremental backup relies on smaller fixed-size units with SHA signatures, that are then combined into variable length extents that get copied -- eseentially a DD with variable blocks and holes.

I'm having some trouble mapping these block-device type copy operations into file systems with metadata.  I understand that if the source and destination are the same type of backend, and that backend basically just puts a file-system on a block device, then there's a pretty good fit.  But how are you proposing to do this kind of backup when the source and destination are not on the same kind of backend?

We added the preserve_metadata in share backup API to check whether we can preserve metadata. The source and destination are not on the same kind of backend, it means it cannot preserve file systems with metadata.

Hi stephenfin, In HostManager._get_host_states method, the host_state_map is None, so we get the HostState object by HostManager.host_state_cls and the initial value of HostState.updated is None.
the judge whether updates or not is in HostState._update_from_compute_node, and the method called chain is  "HostManager._get_host_states-->HostState.update --> HostState._update_from_compute_node". That is the HostState is local variable in HostManager, and update the HostState by compute_nodes in DB with the "HostState.updated=None".

This is a new optional-extra-vars that can be defined in the command line with the option -e.
I think we can change its definition as below.

- The ssl_ca_certificate_file defines the ssl_ca certificate that will be installed during the restore. It will replace the ssl_ca certificate from the backup tar file.

  ssl_ca_certificate_file=<complete path>/<ssl_ca certificate file>
  
  This parameter depends on on_box_data value.
  When on_box_data=true or not defined, the ssl_ca_certificate_file will be the location of ssl_ca certificate file in the target host. This is the default case.
  When on_box_data=false, the ssl_ca_certificate_file will be the location of ssl_ca certificate file where the Ansible controller is running. This is useful for remote play.
... see previous comment on this note ...

The ssl_ca_certificate_file defines a single certificate that contains all the ssl_ca certificates that will be installed during restore. It will replace the /opt/platform/config/<software-version>/ca-cert.pem, that is a single certificate containing all the ssl_ca certificates installed in the host in the time of backup was done. So, the certificate assigned to this parameter must follow the same pattern.

Other options: 
-e restore_mode=optimized
* Enable optimized restore mode
-e "initial_backup_dir=/home/sysadmin"
* Where the backup tgz files are located on box.

* The basename of the platform backup tgz.  The full path will be a combination {initial_backup_dir}/{backup_filename}
-e restore_registry_filesystem=true

-e registry_backup_filename=custom_name_registry_filesystem_backup.tgz
* By default this override is not required.  When restore_registry_filesystem is true and a custom name was used during backup, registry_backup_filename needs to be set to match. The full path will be a combination {initial_backup_dir}/{registry_backup_filename}

neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py.message: Is that enough 5s, should we except the process to finish before that in normal condition?
there should be even a cfg option for this (or a general one that can be used for dnsmasq, keepalived etc...)

In my experience (for which I have NOT done a proper measurement) dnsmasq shuts down pretty fast, generally in under a second (I don't notice it hanging). If it's not done after 5 seconds I'd say dnsmasq had it's chance and should get killed.

For reference, this is what dnsmasq does when it gets a SIGTERM: https://github.com/imp/dnsmasq/blob/master/src/dnsmasq.c#L1586-L1628

Hardcoding this seems to be established practice in Neutron, so I went for this instead of adding an option.

This makes sense to me.

@Thierry: unrelated to this patch, but the text you refer to says "Projects must participate in at least two milestones in order to be considered part of the release."  That doesn't seem to square with the current cycle-with-rc definition: https://releases.openstack.org/reference/release_models.html#cycle-with-rc ... or am I misreading something?

"Participate in milestones" here means slightly different things based on your release model. For cycle-with-rc deliverables, that means issuing a beta release at or before milestone-2. For cycle-with-intermediary, that means at least one release by milestone-2.

The intent here is that release jobs for new deliverables must be ready to serve and successfully exercised at least once by milestone-2, so that the release team does not have to debug those around milestone-3 and the end-of-release crunch. The wording "at least two milestones" is a bit confusing but the idea was that if you "participated" in milestone-1 and milestone-3, you are good too.

Pavlo, I think you misunderstood my patch. I am not trying to solve filtering projects by domain_id for the case described by you. What I am solving is the locking issue, that was causing the exception I reported. 

I am not ignoring the `filter_project`, if you look a the code, 
```
LOG.warning('filtered project not found in keystone,'
                       ' ignoring the filter_project '
                      'option')
self.filter_project = None
```

When the `filter_project` is not found, it is set to `None`, and this causes a problem when multiple concurrent executions are queued by the locking (`with self._gnocchi_project_id_lock`). That is the problem I am solving here. Therefore, the patch you pointed out is not an alternative to this one. They (the patches) are not concurrent, each one of them is solving a different problem. The code continues to do the same as it was before, I just fixed that improper locking code that was coded.

If you ignore this patch in favor of the other you pointed out, the problem still persists.

not sure about the problem with locking, but with this patch you basically ignore the filter_domain.

please see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ceilometer/+/820355 for the proper fix for filtering projects by domain_id, this solves the NoUniqueMatch for the case when e.g. several projects named 'service' are created in different domains.

I don't think your explanation of meaning of 'filter_project' is correct. It not so much here to support 'hosting gnocchi VMs inside openstack'. It is for events that gnocchi as as service itself generates. If we do not filter these out, we will get a self-sustaining loop of "gnocchi generates event/sample -> ceilometer catches it and stores in Gnocchi -> gnocchi emits event/sample that something has been stored -> ..."

So the filter_project should never be set to None, and the "service" is a standard/default project name where service users (e.g. used by ceilometer to access gnocchi) reside.

Hello guys, can somebody help here?

I mean, I have explained the situation, but the person that gave the -1 did not return my response. Is it suppose to be definitive like this? Somebody just slap a -1 somewhere, and then the author promptly responds the issue and explain that it is a misunderstanding, and nobody else jumps in to discuss this further.

Let me stress what I am doing here. <b>I am not changing the logic<b/>. If one takes a look at [1], she/he will be able to see that the variable `self.filter_project=None` is set to None if the project name is not found in Keystone. The default `filter_project` is loaded at [2]. Then, when it is set to None because of code in [1], line [3] will return `False`, which in turn will make the code in [1] not to be called again.

Therefore, I am not changing the logic. The process of setting the "filter_project" to None was already there, and it makes sense. Again, let me repeat; I am not changing the logic.

Now, what am I changing/addressing?

I am fixing concurrency issues that might happen as soon as the first boot/startup of Ceilometer. During that moment different thread might be stopped at line [4], then the first thread that is executed, if it does not find the "filter_project" in Keystone, it will set it to None. Afterwards, the others threads, when they execute, the "filter_project"  is not going to be a name anymore, it is going to be the value None, which will make Keystone to list all projects, which in turn creates an exception because we were expecting a single entry.

Therefore, that is what I am addressing with this patch. I am simply addressing this very specific concurrency issue. No logic/process is changed. The behaviour that was there is maitained.

Do you guys see/understand that? Should I try to explain it with some other words or some more detailed use case?

There is a simple fix for that. Do not enable the DEBUG log level. Only use it when troubleshooting something.

Other parts of Ceilometer, do not help; when we set the LOG level to DEBUG, nothing extra appears. Logs are a very important element of systems, and sadly when there are no extra logs in DEBUG, we make the life of operators a living hell sometimes when troubleshooting issues with the system.

Hi!
It's been a while so I had to re-read the whole thing!

From the point of view of the caller of notify_send, before that patch, we would run _produce_message which would call self.producer.produce and do one of these:
1. Success, break out of the loop, poll(0), and return to notify_send which returns
2. Fail with a KafkaException, LOG an error message, break out of the while True loop, poll(0), and return to notify_send which returns
3. Fail with a BufferError, call self.producer.poll(0.5), and loop back to the call to self.producer.produce

With the proposed patch:
notify_send calls _produce_message with a poll=0 which in turns calls self.producer.produce and do one of these:
1. Success, poll(0), return to notify_send which returns
2. Fail with a KafkaException, poll(0), raise to notify_send which LOGs the error message, breaks out of its loop and returns
3. Fail with a BufferError, raise to notify_send which LOGs a debug message, sets poll to 0.5 and loops back to the call to self.producer.produce

From what I understand, in both cases, as long as the call to _produce_message fails with a BufferError, we poll(0.5). And as soon as _produce_message works (or fail with KafkaException), we end-up leaving notify_send. Subsequent calls to notify_send are started with poll=0. Am I missing something there?

I could not sleep and realized that this is broken for the case when a request has count=3 and placement returns a candidate that allocates 2 devs from RP1 an one from RP2. At this place we dont check that poolA that maps to RP1 actually has two devs.
similarly as above this might not consume the right amount of devs from the right pool. We have to consider the amount of dev requsted per RP that is mapped to pool and consume that

this would also happen for pools created by device specs with physical_network set?
+1 for this otherwise i think im +2

Good catch. 

Devices with physical_network are not mapped to RPs today. If a host has these devices but also the same host has some PCI devices without physical_network so that the scheduler can select this host for a VM with flavor based PCI alias, then this Warning will appear for the host even if the host is actually well configured.

Actually this warning is totally wrong. The case where we have rp_uuids from the scheduler can only happen if the compute host reported PCI inventory otherwise placement won't return candidate for this host. So the only case when this warning actually logged when the host has [pci]report_in_placement enabled but has both type of PCI devices. Therefore pools without RP mapping can be freely ignored without logging anything. So I'm dropping this log and adding some code comments instead in the FUP https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/862876

if there was any error with the find_subnet different than DuplicateResource we might fail with variable subnet not defined. To be on the safe side, it might be better to define it prior to the assignment

kuryr_kubernetes/utils.py.message: Why not a os_net.get_subnet()? That way you don't need to check if list len matches 1.
I wonder if this shouldn't be fatal instead. Also message needs context that it's about primarySubnet value. In which case it should probably be generated outside of this function.

Hm. So let me do that other way around: if os_net.get_subnet finds subnet (which indicates uuid has been used as a string) or there is exactly one named subnet (which means subnet name) than we will return subnet id or None with proper log. I'm wondering, should we, in case of miss-configuration, raise an exception?

Technically at the moment we do that in somewhat opportunistic fashion - if we find a subnet configured, we add it to the list. This means you're right that "fatal" as in "raise exception" is probably not the best way to do it. But if we have some kind of doubt (several subnets with the same name) it might be better to play it safe here and just not add it. Otherwise we might add too many addresses to the SGs, meaning a minor security risk.

To knikolla

Hi,

Please allow me to ask additional questions about what we discussed at the last meeting.
 
1. You mentioned the Federation API. I understood it's just a similar example, and you didn't intend to use it for this purpose. Is that correct? 

2. You and dmendiza suggested requiring DN (I think it must be CN, am I correct? please see Note1) or SAN to match the username [1]. Is it possible to assume that multiple clients cannot have the same CN or SAN?

Note1: The DN is something like "CN=%s,O=%s,L=%s,ST=%s,C=%s". It's weird to be used as username.

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/meetings/keystone/2022/keystone.2022-08-02-15.00.log.html#l-95

1. Yes, Federation is just a similar API.

2. Yes, CN is correct, or we could also use SAN.  We probably need a username + domain_name combination since usernames are only unique within their domain.  Maybe we can specify both the username and domain name somewhere in the DN?

Looking at [1] it may make sense to use "UID=username,DC=domain_name" as part of the DN.  Then we could use those values to match the user and domain in Keystone.

Since the CA is the identity provider in this case, the CA would need to ensure that it only issues DN="...,UID=usernam,DC=domain_name,..." based on some criteria that you can define.

We'll need to document what parts of the DN are being used to match users and domains.

[1] https://www.cryptosys.net/pki/manpki/pki_distnames.html

I've updated spec based on the previous meeting.
We're investigating the existing OS-FEDERATION mapping API so I'll elaborate on how we configure the mapping in our case.

To complete this spec, I also need to make the things below clear so please kindly tell me if you have an answer.

1. about delegation of users' permission
In my understanding, OAuth2.0 clients have to be delegated roles from a specific user, however it's not possible if we register OAuth2.0 client as the keystone user. For example, it's not possible for non-admin user who is only allowed to access Tacker API to delegate it's role to a client whereas it's possible if we use credentials API and allow this user to access the credentials API. It's not a big deal while we only assume non-admin and admin users, but might be a problem when we want to use more fine-grained roles. How can we justify (or explain) this limitation?

2. feasibility of diverting the existing mapping API  
After briefly looking at some sources of the existing mapping API, I feel we can divert this existing API for our usecase (i.e., we don't have to build a similar mechanism from scratch). For example, we can register our mapping rule to the mapping API, and use it when authenticating an OAuth2.0 client. Does that match your thoughts?

> the CA would need to ensure that it only issues DN="...,UID=usernam,DC=domain_name,..." based on some criteria that you can define.

I think we can't always enforce CA to follow the rule of Keystone. The mapping between fields of the DN and Keystone user's attributes changes depending on use cases of PKI. For example, if we have to use `project_id` but not `domain_name` to specify the users' tenant, there are several candidates of mapping such as `UID=username, OU=project_id` or `CN=username, DC=project_id`. In this sense, we have to make users change such mapping freely.

It's a little bit complicated. If we just store entire DN into credentials API as we thought at first, we don't have to think about such mapping. 

The options are:
- Use User API to store part of the DN Add the configuration of mapping between the DN and keystone user's attributes like federation API [1]
- Use Credentials API to store entire DN (note that we can make it without any modification to Credentials API)

Which do you think better? or do you have other options?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/pike/advanced-topics/federation/mapping_combinations.html
Let's move this spec to target the antelope cycle

specs/keystone/zed/support-oauth2-mtls.r.message: Can you clarify for me: Credential Id would be the fingerprint of the certificate? Or is it that the DN will be the Credential Id?

> Credential Id would be the fingerprint of the certificate? Or is it that the DN will be the Credential Id?

No, I meant that credential Id can be a key to obtain DN from DB.
As DN is stored as a data (or blob) of Credentials [1], we can retrieve DN corresponding to a given credential Id. I'll elaborate on this in the next patch.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/?expanded=validate-and-show-information-for-token-detail,password-authentication-with-unscoped-authorization-detail,authenticating-with-an-application-credential-detail#credentials
Thanks, this makes sense
Revised this line in PS10

How is the middleware authenticated through mutual TLS? Does it read a header from the web server with the contents of the certificate?

Could all public endpoints be authenticated through mTLS? What about internal TLS encrypted endpoints?
As discussed in a previous meeting, I added the description that the configuration of mutual TLS for other endpoints is out-of-scope of the present document in the PS12.
Ack

> How is the middleware authenticated through mutual TLS?

I thought it's possible by registering the middleware as a OAuth2.0 client as well as API clients, but on think it over, "authenticated through the
OAuth2.0 mutual TLS" is not a requirement. So I'll revise it.

One thing clear to me is that if we setup mTLS on Keystone, all clients connecting to Keystone have to use mTLS even if a client uses an internal endpoint.
This happens because, in my understanding, flask (i.e., a server of Keystone) cannot change the settings of mTLS for each endpoint (i.e., using mTLS for access token API but NOT using it for token verification API is not possible).
Revised this line in PS10

What I was thinking is that the TLS termination would usually be done by the web server, not flask. Looking at the available configuration in Apache and Nginx, there is usually an option to enable Mutual TLS, like "SSLVerifyClient require", you also provide the CA, and you can configure headers that can be later read by the middleware (or keystone itself).

What I wonder about, is the multiple different kinds of configurations that we want to support. TripleO for example has TLS Everywhere, where all internal endpoints are TLS terminated, but I guess this is out of scope for this implementation.

I guess we can configure keystone and other services with multiple endpoints, if we want to support Mutual TLS and non-mutual TLS clients, but maybe that wouldn't be considered secure, if we use an all or nothing approach? Maybe there is just one common usecase here, that we could describe here, that we want to support, like MTLS-only, enabled for all public endpoints.
so this will not work with self-signed certificates?

Basically yes.
I guess the thing behind this question is that RFC8705 describes a case where a self-signed certificate is used. Our use case is PKI and I've just thought it's a little bit safer to start by only supporting PKI though it depends on use cases.

If you think it's better to support self-signed certificate, please let me know. I guess it's also not a big deal from an implementation standpoint to make.
how will this be performed over mTLs if the server doesn't trust the clients certificate yet? I don't think this step requires mTLS.

> how will this be performed over mTLs if the server doesn't trust the clients certificate yet? 

To be sure, it doesn't mean authenticating the User with its certificate. The User authenticate with a fernet token (password), but the server also verifies the trust chain of the User's certificate and the possession of a private key corresponding to the certificate. As long as Keystone and the User use the same root CA certificate, it works.

> I don't think this step requires mTLS.

As you said, this step doesn't require mTLS even though it works.
The reason I wrote "(over mutual TLS)" is that I don't think it's possible to disable mTLS only on '/v3/credentials'. If we configure mTLS in Keystone, clients have to use mTLS for all Identity APIs (e.g., `/v3/auth/tokens`, `v3/credentials`, etc.). If you know it's wrong, please tell me.

Maybe such limitation shouldn't appear on here as it's confusing. I'll once remove it in the PS11. If you disagree with my decision, please kindly leave a new comment.
will the credential be limited to a project the same way that application credentials are?
yes.
The RFC makes binding optional. Is your intention to make it required?

Yes.
As you and RFC8705 Sec. 1 mentioned, we can separate Mutual-TLS certificate-bound access tokens and Mutual-TLS client authentication, but we think it doesn't much make sense for the following reason.

If we want to disable (or ignore) the binding, we can simply use OAuth2.0 keystonemiddleware in Yoga [1]. This middleware performs the token validation for OAuth2.0 token in the Authorization header, but doesn't check the thumbprint of the client certificate. 

I know it may not completely meet the RFC8705, but actually whether or not verifying a thumbprint bound to an access token is a protected resource (API server) matter as described in RFC8705 Sec. 3.2 [2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystonemiddleware/+/830737
[2] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8705#section-3.2
at the same time as what?
It's not necessary. Removed in the PS11.
so just to confirm, this will be the thumbprint to validate the binding?

It's a thumbprint. 
Fixed in the PS11

Also, removed the sentence after `or` (i.e., `or credential Id...`) as thumbprint is small enough to be store in the fernet token.
Can you please elaborate on this?

This is what I tried to explain in the above comment [1].
I made this line a note and explain what I wrote in [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone-specs/+/843765/comment/27750f08_4eab145c/

Sorry, on second thought, I feel writing this in the spec is inappropriate, so I removed it in PS12. Please see the comment [1].
I guess there some ways to break this limitation [2], such as adding additional endpoints. Maybe xek pointed out this option, if my understanding is correct.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone-specs/+/843765/comment/27750f08_4eab145c/
[2] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8705#section-5
We can also add the thumbprint to fernet tokens.

I fixed the description about fernet tokens two comments above.

As you know, JWT (i.e., JWS in Keystone) is not encrypted whereas fernet token is encrypted. The way to validate them can be different. in JWT, token metadata can be retrieved from a token directly while, in fernet token, token metadata has to be obtained via communication with keystone to decrypt the token.
As discussed in the previous meeting, I would prefer not to do this.
Removed this alternative in the PS11.
In the case of adding fields to a token, this will slightly increase the token size, so there will be a slight performance impact.
Described the performance impact in the PS11.

  API has been deprecated

   self.log.warning(

openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py.message: so, funny thing, this doesn't actually do anything fwict. It's accepted by the server but I don't see it appearing in results. Not sure if it's an environment issue but I see the same thing with novaclient

Okay, this is a bug in openstacksdk. It's not providing a microversion so nova is silently ignoring this argument. Running this command with the '--debug' flag on master yields:

  REQ: curl -g -i -X POST http://10.0.108.84/compute/v2.1/servers/111bada5-569c-4681-a937-2892a4ef6d8a/action
  -H "Accept: application/json"
  -H "Content-Type: application/json"
  -H "OpenStack-API-Version: compute 2.88"
  -H "User-Agent: python-novaclient"
  -H "X-Auth-Token: {SHA256}a7b39ac71db0ccfe5b3108cca734a71ad300245c132d5d19ec41b34e15589d12"
  -H "X-OpenStack-Nova-API-Version: 2.88"
  -d '{"lock": {"locked_reason": "foobar"}}'

Whereas running it with openstacksdk (this patch) yields:

  REQ: curl -g -i -X POST http://10.0.108.84/compute/v2.1/servers/111bada5-569c-4681-a937-2892a4ef6d8a/action
  -H "Accept: "
  -H "Content-Type: application/json"
  -H "User-Agent: openstacksdk/0.61.0 keystoneauth1/4.4.0 python-requests/2.26.0 CPython/3.8.12"
  -H "X-Auth-Token: {SHA256}8ae338c3e44ea2e44ba5fa21b22d836583a44a78c15048cfb60a52fb70eab5ef"
  -d '{"lock": {"locked_reason": "foobar"}}'

Notice this line is missing:

  -H "OpenStack-API-Version: compute 2.88"

We'll need another release of openstacksdk, unfortunately 😞

Eventlet sets it for us -- on py2, it does so correctly; on py3, we had to capture it early since we were going to rewrite the request line to be something cpython could actually parse correctly (see https://bugs.python.org/issue33973).

do we get to turn this back on after we backport our http parsing fix?

Would have to wait until we cut a stable release post-backport, but yeah, there exists a path wherein we get this turned back on. Historically, we don't have a great track record of actually doing it for stable branches, though -- master is front of mind, and stable tends to be an afterthought. Master is in basically all ways better, we do our best to ensure you can always upgrade to it, so stable tags tend to be infrequent. As a result, there's often some new form of breakage that would prevent us from re-enabling.

If we wanted to be serious about it, we might want to have a known-failures file for things like this -- but I think it'd be hard to get the scoping right. It's always some dependency that shifts and causes us headaches, so it's weird to list known-failures by Swift release; OTOH, there *should be* a known Swift release that contains a workaround to get it passing again.

If I was more principled I'd say this is obviously a regression and push to get a revert upstream.  But even as lazy as I am, I wouldn't write THIS patch until after it became obvious 1) people need swift to work on this broken version of python and 2) python maintainers aren't going to fix their broken python releases - then MAYBE I'd think the right thing to do is paper over their mess.

Do you have an upstream bug report for this regression?  Do you have any reason to believe swift is alone in getting hozed by this recent regression or that everyone else plans to capitulate to stdlib shipping a broken http parser forever?  What python versions are effected - do we have to have gating tests on those versions?

> I suppose I should at least write the bug, though...

https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/99220

> 1) people need swift to work on this broken version of python

As already linked, upstream's already released fixes to py37-py311. The only question now is how long it's going to take for distros to pick up the patch.

> 2) python maintainers aren't going to fix their broken python releases

My experience with submitting cpython bugs has me skeptical that this would ever get addressed. (My bellwethers have been https://bugs.python.org/issue33973 / https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/7932 and https://bugs.python.org/issue37093 / https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/13788 -- I was so hopeful years ago that phrases like "request-smuggling vector" could actually elicit some response.) I suppose I should at least write the bug, though...

> stdlib shipping a broken http parser forever

That's the thing -- even if we push stdlib to fix their issue better, in a way that doesn't break us by default -- they've got releases out with the fix now. They have now *forever* shipped a broken parser that may get picked up by distros. Are we so sure we *don't* want to support them?

I kinda dread having to say something like "Oh yeah, swift supports py39 -- well, except 3.9.14 and 3.9.15 -- if you're on *them* make sure you upgrade to 3.9.16+" and that's *before* we get to things like whatever crazy cherry-picking of patches RH (for example) might apply...

I see three options, none of which are great:

* we do something brittle like this and continue using stdlib under the hood for HTTP parsing
* we bring in a new dependency like h11 (either ourselves or by pushing eventlet to adopt it) and try to discover the new ways that parsing is broken (while probably needing to address https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1496636 much sooner than we have thus far had the will to do)
* we write our own HTTP parser, which is likely to be chock full of its own bugs

Devil-you-know seems like it may well be least-bad :-/

I understood from earlier discussion (maybe verbal) that the cpython "feature" has shipped, back-ported, and will forever be in some versions of python. If that understanding is correct then we either stop supporting a bunch of python versions (all future until the cpython changes), or we need to take some action.

Assuming we choose to take some action, then there's obviously differing opinions as to what code we should write and maintain. Is anyone able to work on an alternative patchset?

Pete, thanks for looking at this!  Do you have any pull with red hat or cpython maintainers that might get eyes on https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/99220

The one thing we haven't done is tried to find a more reasonable fix for https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/87389 (a bug in the *server*) that accidently tricked them into thinking they can break the *protocol* handler.

Instead of stripping the leading /'s before they ever get to the environ they should have just gone into to the thing that wasn't properly sanitizing it's inputs before sending them to the filesystem.  Fix THAT and you don't need to break the parser.  It might be easy:

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/main/Lib/http/server.py#L834

This seems like a necessary evil - we've been forced into this kludge by the lib bug. Tim's concern about breaking out methods is reasonable, so I don't want to stand in the way for the sake of test elegance. It doesn't seem any of us came up with a smarter way to count number of '/' at the start of string.

It does sound better to me to fix the file system issue closer to the file system in the stack.

I'll see what I can do about talking to our Python people. But they seem to be only doing packaging.

This is not the way. I think we'd be way smarter/happier long term to just inline the entire non-broken parse_request method from before it grew a stupid regex in the middle:

https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/24848/files#diff-10e6db6c775e351ba2b55c4ad5e177191afe25d4942d1d2162d6e10505788a81R340

... we can even inline our py3 bytes_to_wsgi translation, SAVE a stack trace and call the whole investment an optimization.

“Find the dependencies — and eliminate them.” When you’re working on a really, really good team with great programmers, everybody else’s code, frankly, is bug-infested garbage, and nobody else knows how to ship on time. 

https://www.joelonsoftware.com/2001/10/14/in-defense-of-not-invented-here-syndrome/

this is the wrong issue to reference.  I get it - they had a CVE to deal with there was a new contributer and they assumed no-one was doing anything remotely serious with stdlib httpserver stack, but eventlet.wsgi and wsgiref do, so the "bug" that's causing us to carry this inline runtime hack is:

https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/99220

... and maybe no one cares?

If the path was more clear to me how eventlet (and other greenlet/stack-swapping) platforms were going to evolve into or cooperate with modern asyncio eventloops - I'd say we should invest in *fixing* eventlet.wsgi to not depend on broken http parsers.  There's good options out there:

    * https://github.com/python-hyper/h11/
    * https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/

... but since the path is not clear to me, and eventlet might be just as barely "maintained" as the stdlib http parser - maybe instead of "fixing" eventlet.wsgi we could just open a bug to try and get more eyes on the cpyhton bug?

test/unit/common/test_wsgi.py.message: the test scaffolding seems to be quite fragile: I wonder if the goal of this test might be better realised by breaking the cleanup code out to a help method and testing that directly?

I can't follow this thread - it sounds like we're talking about two different things.  The test does look dumb to me on the surface and I don't think we can implicitly blame that on the unit under test.  The more that we're going to have to maintain the behaviors we want from our http parser w/o 3rd party changes breaking us the more we'll have to test (and refactor to be more testable).

I think that's mostly because *our current HTTP parsing* is quite fragile -- as evidenced by this breakage from something that's two steps removed from us! It's duct-tape, paperclips, and shoe string the whole way down :-(

As to the tactics: I think the only way to have the helper-method approach improve things is to have the `if self.requestline.startswith(...):` inside the helper and always call the helper... but IDK that I really want to add the extra function call at such a low level of every request. I suppose there are already plenty of comparable function calls, but surely at some point it starts to have a noticeable impact, no?

we're litterally installing the bad behavior we're claiming exists in our depdendency so that we can assert we fix it.

this test doesn't seem reasonable to me.

If we *did* convince upstream to fix the break, the test would no longer verify the fix! We might rip it all out, revert the whole patch, because our CI got an upgraded python -- despite there potentially being users out there still affected. I feel like I can't win here :-(

I think Al sounds like he has a pretty clear picture of some imporeoved behavior based testing that we could apply here - seems like sound technical investment to me.  If not *right now* does the oppertunity cost calculus change after the new year?
So, what's the answer? Maybe it's "not test this at all" and if something breaks we'll know?
as above, maybe create a separate method to do the '/'-mangling and test it directly? then a test that asserts the various helper methods are called.

kubernetes/k8s-cni-cache-cleanup/centos/.message: This grep would also catch the case that kubelet is 'inactive'.  Suggest to make a local variable to check $(systemctl is-active kubelet) then do a string comparison for 'active'
Done. I decided to use a variable and compare it because by just running the command as the check, the output "active" was just getting thrown around and assigned to the "kubelet_uptime" variable.

The return code from just the systemctl command itself is all that is needed to indicate whether or not kubelet is active, no grepping required.  You can even use the --quiet option to suppress the "active" or "inactive" string output.

From the systemctl man page:
is-active PATTERN...
           Check whether any of the specified units are active (i.e. running). Returns an exit code 0 if at least one is active, or non-zero otherwise. Unless --quiet is specified, this will also print the
           current unit state to standard output.

You should structure the call so that you capture the return code of the systemctl command (not awk) so in case the show command fails you can debug.  Only proceed to awk the output if the command succeeded.

eg. kubelet_ts_property=....show kubelet...
RC=${?}
if RC is good
  kubelet_uptime=$( echo "${kubelet_ts_property}" | awk ... )
It's good form to use double quotes around variable dereferences to protect against such variable containing null and potentially causing a syntax error in the script.

Why use two statements to get here, why not just eg:

if [ -z "${kubelet_uptime}" ]; then
    ERROR "Failed to get kubelet uptime, RC=${RC}"

Yes.

sysadmin@controller-0:~$ systemctl show kubelet --property blahblah
sysadmin@controller-0:~$ echo $?
0

It gives a 0 rc even if the property doesn't exist.
If I do a check on the RC value and it's good. Do I still need to do the "if [ -z "${kubelet_uptime}" ]" check
Always put out the return code in such a log to give somebody a hope in hell of debugging it.

After review against your definitions, I feel like they should all be shifted by 1 based on the definitions in RFC 5424 (1-6).  I think I’m ok to leave them as is since they are simply mapped to the highest severities, but there are some discrepancies.

1 – critical

0       Emergency: system is unusable

              2       Critical: critical conditions
              3       Error: error conditions

              5       Notice: normal but significant condition
              6       Informational: informational messages

Hello Rajat,

>> The mock seems suspicious here

mock -> collections.namedtuple in the next patch (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/851640)

we are not updating the provider_location, is this intentional?

Hello Rajat,

Thank you very much for the review!

>> we are not updating the provider_location, is this intentional?

Yes. The Infinidat driver does not use the provider_location (iSCSI/FC host/target/port/LUN information is defined dynamically and may change when the storage system is reconfigured).

But we change the provider_location value to None to clear the current value during volume migration. For example, in case of migration a volume from the generic NFS driver, the volume has an existing non-empty provider_location value, and we must clear it when we migrate the volume to the Infinidat backend:

$ cinder create --volume-type nfs 1
$ cinder list --fields id,volume_type
+--------------------------------------+-------------+
| ID                                   | Volume_Type |
+--------------------------------------+-------------+
| 901e8129-fb67-4495-b111-e8df2eb94ea7 | nfs         |
+--------------------------------------+-------------+
mysql> select provider_location from volumes where id='901e8129-fb67-4495-b111-e8df2eb94ea7';
+---------------------+
| provider_location   |
+---------------------+
| 172.10.20.123:/nfs  |
+---------------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

$ cinder retype --migration-policy on-demand 901e8129-fb67-4495-b111-e8df2eb94ea7 iscsi
$ cinder list --fields id,volume_type
+--------------------------------------+-------------+
| ID                                   | Volume_Type |
+--------------------------------------+-------------+
| 901e8129-fb67-4495-b111-e8df2eb94ea7 | iscsi       |
+--------------------------------------+-------------+
mysql> select provider_location from volumes where id='901e8129-fb67-4495-b111-e8df2eb94ea7';
+-------------------+
| provider_location |
+-------------------+
| NULL              |
+-------------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

And in the absence of {'provider_location': None}, we will have the old value from the NFS driver (172.10.20.123:/nfs)

Thank you very much!

I assume name_id is specific to backend so when performing migration, we want to use the common thing between backends i.e. the volume ID
Looks like using `migration=True` here keeps backwards compatibility with old volumes.

Thanks for the patch. Please find one comment inline.
Otherwise LGTM.

-1 due to my comment in openstack_dashboard/api/keystone.py. It needs to be fixed apparently.

Regarding my question on the motivation of this patch, I would like to clarify it before I vote.

Can I ask a very basic question before moving this forward?
What kind of deployments need horizon uses a different endpoint type ONLY for keystone? (for example, "internal" for keystone only and "public" for others)

- If users of your OpenStack cloud is allowed to use OpenStack APIs, all services provided including keystone requires "public" endpoint. If so, there is no need for horizon to use "internal" endpoint type for keystone.
- If users of your OpenStack cloud is not allowed to use OpenStack API directly and need to use horizon to access the cloud, there is no need for "public" and it would be enough to set OPENSTACXK_ENDPOINT_TYPE to "internal" in horizon (Or you can still use "public" endpoint in a private network segment).

I am wondering why you need to use a different endpoint type only for keystone and would like to understand the detail reason on why your patch is needed.

P.S. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/horizon/+/730781 you mentioned in the commit message did not intend the removal of "internal" endpoint usage for keystone. Before that, the situation was worse. some code referred to OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE (which defaults to "public") and some other code (you touched in this patch) referred to the hardcoded "internal" endpoint type, so as a result both of "internal" and "public" were required when the default setting was used. If you would like to use "internal" endpoint for keystone completely, you needed to set OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE to "internal".

Even after I agree with the motivation, I still have several comments.

- KeystoneBackend.authenticate() in openstack_auth/backend.py refers to OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE. Doesn't it need to refer to the new setting?
- user_verify_admin_password() in openstack_dashboard/api/keystone.py uses a hardcoded "publicURL" endpoint type. Don't you need to use the new setting?
- I personally prefer to changing OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE to accept the following dict like below in addition to the string version currently used. It allows us to keep the code handling OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE in a single place (using a function).

  OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE = {
    'identity': 'internal',
    'default': 'public',
  }
Thanks, LGTM

1. Fixed
2. Fixed
3. That could be done, but to respect deployment tooling I'd rather add a config option than change the formatting of an existing one from string to dict.
Fixed, see comment below.

We have a very strict networking design that has Horizon and Keystone into it's own "trusted zone" that is isolated from other zones containing a region.

A trusted zone that contains a region is only allowed to talk to Keystone through the public endpoint into the trusted zone where Keystone is located and cannot talk to any internal or admin endpoint.

Customers access Horizon through the public endpoint into the trusted zone where Horizon (and Keystone) is located. Inside the trusted zone you don't have access to talk to the public endpoint, that means services inside the trusted zone can only talk to each other on an internal or admin endpoint.

The public endpoint in our case is working as an application firewall and due to that and network design the public endpoint is not accessible internally in a trusted zone.

Because of above, we need Horizon to talk to Keystone on an internal endpoint but talk to public endpoint for other services in a region since that would traverse to a different trusted zone where the same logic is applied.

Based on what you wrote in your P.S this also means Horizon has had more than one place where the logic has been hardcoded and is thus a reason why we've had to workaround that issue by whitelisting a recirculating pattern in the application firewall to make it work.
I will write down a more complete explaination on why we need this.
